_exec_summary.SummaryText:
The Fayette County Water System Risk Management Plan (RMP) for Safe Chlorine Handling involves a unified approach that integrates technologies, procedures, and management practices to monitor potential chlorine hazards and reduce the risk of accidental chlorine releases.  All applicable procedures of the U.S. Environmental Protection Agency (EPA) Prevention Program are addressed in the plan, which seeks to provide for employee safety, public health and response agency interaction.

The Crosstown Water Treatment Plant (WTP) uses chlorine to disinfect surface water from Lake Peachtree, Lake Horton, Starr's Mill Pond, and Line Creek.  The plant can process up to 13,500,000 gallons per day and is at 3500 TDK Boulevard in Peachtree City, Georgia.  The Water System provides drinking water to residents in Fayette County, Peachtree City, Tyrone, Woolsey, and, if needed, Fayetteville and Brooks.  Industrial users are primarily concentrated in the Peachtree City industrial area.

Chlorine is added to the water treatment process at two locations, and due to facility design, chlorine is stored at two separate buildings.  Chlorine stored at the Pretreatment Chemical Building is used to control biological growth through the sedimentation and filtration processes.  Chlorine stored at the Filtration Building is used to chlorinate filtered water and provide a biologically safe product.  The chlorination process includes chlorine gas stored as a liquid under pressure in chlorine containers, chlorination equipment, an instrument room, electrical equipment, and process specific safety equipment.  The facility is manned twenty-four hours a day.

Chlorine is a toxic gas that is irritating and corrosive to the eyes, skin, and respiratory tract.  To define the potential off-site impacts to the public and the environment from a chlorine release, Off-site Consequence Analysis was done to identify the impact circle, or area of concern, associated with two chlorine gas release scenarios.  The

worst-case scenario, defined by the EPA, states that the owner or operator shall assume that the maximum quantity in the largest vessel is released as a gas over ten minutes.  Under Program 2 processes, the owner or operator is required to identify and analyze at least one alternative scenario that is "more likely" to occur than the worst-case scenario. An alternative scenario for the Crosstown WTP was chosen based on the most typical release situation.  The EPA recognizes that alternative scenarios are more useful for emergency response preparedness and planning than the worst-case scenario.

For each scenario, the EPA RMP*Comp dispersion modeling program was used to determine the impact radius, or the distance the chlorine gas travels from the point of release before the concentration  in the air falls below a health-based value referred to as the toxic endpoint.  The theoretical toxic endpoint is based on the Emergency Response Planning Guideline Level 2 (ERPG-2) concentrations developed by the American Industrial Hygiene Association.  EPRG-2 is defined as the maximum airborne concentration below which it is believed that nearly all individuals could be exposed for up to one hour without experiencing or developing irreversible or other serious health effects or symptoms that could impair an individual's ability to take protective action.  The toxic endpoint for chlorine gas in air is 3 parts per million (ppm) by volume.

The worst-case release scenario for the Crosstown Water Treatment Plant involves the failure of a one-ton container yielding a total release of 2,000 lbs. of chlorine over a 10-minute period.  RMP*Comp calculated the distance to the toxic endpoint as 1.3 miles.  The receptors within the impact circle include major commercial and industrial areas, recreation areas, an airfield, and a residential population of twenty-seven hundred (2700).

The alternative release scenario for the chlorination process involves a tubing failure, bad connection, or va

lve failure resulting in the release of chlorine gas from  a one-ton container through a 5/16-inch-diameter valve body opening over a one hour period.  Chlorine tanks in use at the Crosstown WTP are placed in an enclosed room.  Therefore, the release would occur in an enclosed space but not air tight.  RMP*Comp gave an impact radius of 0.1 miles under normal atmospheric conditions.  There is no residential population, and only one recreational area, within the impact circle.

An accident history review found no incident that resulted in either on-site or off-site death, injury, evacuation, sheltering in place, property damage, or environmental damage in the past five years.  

The Fayette County Water System's Risk Management Program includes the following key elements to mitigate the effects of potential chlorine release hazards:
    Operator Training
    Preventive maintenance program
    Process specific safety equipment
    Safe and effective standard operating procedures
    Hazard review of equipment and procedures
    Inspection program

Further, the Water System safety program has the following elements specifically supporting the safe handling of chlorine and the chlorination process:
    Chlorine detectors
    Chemical right to know program
    Respiratory protection (SCBA) program

The Water System coordinates emergency response activities with local response agencies to ensure that they will be prepared to respond to an emergency at the Crosstown WTP.  As a department of Fayette County government, the Water System is active in the Local Emergency Planning Committee (LEPC).  Members of the LEPC, including the Peachtree City Fire Department and the Fayette County Fire and Emergency Services, has developed the Fayette County High Risk Evacuation Plan to ensure that the community has a strategy for responding to and mitigating the threat posed by a release.
